content.webTitle: Claudio Ranieri all smiles as Leicester prepare for visit of Newcastle

fields.headline: Claudio Ranieri all smiles as Leicester prepare for visit of Newcastle
fields.bodyText: Claudio Ranieri is so amiable that he makes a point of shaking hands with every journalist who attends his weekly press conferences at Leicester City’s King Power Stadium. It is a stark contrast to his predecessor, Nigel Pearson, who in the same room after a 3-1 defeat by Chelsea 10 months ago described a reporter who questioned him as an “ostrich” who had his “head in the sand”, before storming out in a huff. However, as the surprise Premier League leaders prepare for the first of their nine remaining matches this season, against Newcastle United on Monday night, in what could end up being the football story to end all stories Ranieri was keen to stress that he did possess a nasty side as well. “This season not often. At the moment, no,” the Italian replied when asked if he ever raised his voice to his players. “But I am very clear in my face if I am angry. I change my face immediately and you understand if I am angry with you.” With his team five points clear of Tottenham Hotspur at the top of the table, one wonders whether Leicester’s players have experienced that at all this season. Ranieri has picked up where Pearson left off 11 months ago, with the club having won 24 and drawn 10 of their past 38 matches since beating West Ham United at home on 4 April - a total of 82 points. “I don’t like to speak a lot,” Ranieri said. “I just say little things so they feel I am behind them. That is important for me. I prefer a good relationship. I have to tell them ‘You don’t play’, but it’s important they do everything right because in my career I always need somebody, so it’s important at the right moment, when I call you, you are ready to play. “Something special happens if all the team are working well because a manager always needs all his players, not only the first XI. Sometimes the other players are more important than the first XI, because when you call one of them it’s important they believe something could happen with them.” Leicester’s success this season has been built on a consistent team selection, with Ranieri having used only 23 players in the Premier League – fewer than any other club. The Italian was known as “the Tinkerman” at Chelsea for his propensity to make wholesale changes for every match but admitted the squad he inherited from Pearson had enabled him to send out a more settled side each week. Yet despite his shift in attitudes, Ranieri insisted that he remained fond of his old moniker. “Now everybody is a Tinkerman but the flag is mine. I was the first,” he said with a smile. “I moved a lot of players only in the last season at Chelsea when new players arrived after the start of the Premier League. [Roman] Abramovich came in at the beginning of July and at that point we started to buy new players, so it was normal that I changed players. Because of that I was the Tinkerman, but that is OK because I changed a lot. New players arrived so I had to put in new players and we finished second. “Some players start to play straight away in the Premier League but other players need more months. Then you have to change things and move things.” Leicester are likely to retain the side that beat Watford last week despite an impressive display from substitute Jeff Schlupp at Vicarage Road. Indeed, 13 of Leicester’s squad have made 20 or more appearances in the Premier League already and Ranieri knows that consistency has been crucial to their success. “I see a very good level and fitness, so why do I have to change? If I see somebody a little tired during a game or a training session, maybe I can change.”
